sentence: In recent years, investor worries about valuation usually have focused on high-multiple, high-growth stocks.
Shopify (NYSE:) and Roku (NASDAQ:) are two of the better examples.
Both stocks trade at seemingly obscene multiples relative to revenue, let alone profits.
But both stocks have soared: ROKU gained 355% in 2019, and SHOP 187%.
Even among stocks that havenÃ¢ÂÂt performed as well Ã¢ÂÂ or even well Ã¢ÂÂ investors have pointed to potential bubbles.
2019 initial public offerings like Uber (NYSE:), Lyft (NASDAQ:), and Peloton Interactive (NASDAQ:) brought a wave of unprofitable companies to the market.
Many of last yearÃ¢ÂÂs IPOs have declined from their opening prices and remain dogged by claims of overvaluation.
But valuation worries arenÃ¢ÂÂt just the province of high-growth tech plays.
During this bull market, older, quality stocks have seen their valuations creep ever higher.
It was not that long ago that low-growth companies struggled to receive even a 20x price-to-earnings multiple.
With U.S. stocks as a whole near all-time highs, and the S&P 500 up nearly 400% from 2009 lows, multiples close to 25x are not uncommon.
Can that multiple expansion continue for even the marketÃ¢ÂÂs highest-quality companies?
ItÃ¢ÂÂs a key question for U.S. stocks.
TuesdayÃ¢ÂÂs big stock charts focus on three names for which that question is paramount.
All three companies unquestionably are among the best on U.S. markets.
But the question, from both near-term and long-term perspectives, is to what extent their stocks already price in that quality.
When we covered McDonaldÃ¢ÂÂs (NYSE:) in our big stock charts in early November, MCD stock was in freefall.
At the time, the chart strongly suggested shares would keep falling.
But the stock found a bottom, and has rallied nicely in the new year, already gaining 8.9%.
Just shy of all-time highs, the first of TuesdayÃ¢ÂÂs big stock charts does suggest there should be more upside ahead.

But valuation is a worry, and itÃ¢ÂÂs possible a top could emerge as suddenly as the November bottom did:
• Fundamentally, the case gets a bit dicier.
It was only a few years ago that McDonaldÃ¢ÂÂs stock traded at a high-teen multiple to forward earnings.
The figure now is over 23x.
A dividend yield consistently over 3% has shrunk to 2.3%.
The launch of and a Ã¢ÂÂrefranchisingÃ¢ÂÂ effort under former chief executive officer Steve Easterbrook drove much of the rally over the past five years.
Those catalysts, however, have played out.
For cable provider Charter Communications (NASDAQ:), in this market thereÃ¢ÂÂs only one question: what stops the rally?

The second of our big stock charts doesnÃ¢ÂÂt have an answer:
• But fundamentally, the core question is: how much longer can this really go?
CHTR now trades at a whopping 27x forward earnings.
ThatÃ¢ÂÂs a multiple more than double that of rival Comcast (NASDAQ:).
There are reasons for the gap Ã¢ÂÂ Charter has an opportunity to take customers from struggling telecom rivals, for instance Ã¢ÂÂ but even in that context the difference in valuation is stunning.
CharterÃ¢ÂÂs history is impressive, but it too is dealing with declines in video and voice subscribers.
• Like McDonaldÃ¢ÂÂs, Charter needs investors to keep paying premium multiples (or higher) for premium companies.
But the stock highlights just how far those multiples have gone.

Shares have more than doubled since December 2018; companies with a market capitalization over $50 billion (as Charter did at those lows) very rarely do see those kinds of gains in such a short period of time.
The valuation gap between the two cable stocks is stunning.
Somewhat quietly, Sherwin-Williams (NYSE:) has been one of the best stocks of the past decade.
Shares have risen nearly 800% over the last ten years, and have doubled in a little over three.

But the third of our big stock charts suggests caution, due in part to one key characteristic that differentiates SHW from other expensive, high-quality names:
